matter's simple - the haitian's are untouchable in pacifica, understood? no kindapping, harvesting chrome or organs, no light-hearted tussles either. those VDB lunatics have been getting touchy lately about their influence in pacifica. so just behave - keep it civil.

SAMUIL EGOROV: want something from the stadium?
DARYA ALEXEEVA: get me some neurosig boosters
SAMUIL EGOROV: for the zetatech gear?
DARYA ALEXEEVA: yea
DARYA ALEEXEVA: why u goin there?
SAMUIL EGOROV: I have to take care of a patient from damir
SAMUIL EGOROV: he's asking for help
DARYA ALEXEEVA: thought he only got people from us?
SAMUIL EGOROV: not always
SAMUIL EGOROV: this time its a proper procedure
Archived Conversation: Samuil Egorov and Darya Alexeeva

A Voodoo Boy netrunner involved in the remote hacking of corporate engineers' implants. At the age of five, he could disassemble and reconstruct a cyberdeck faster than a NetWatch agent inputing their access code. But when you're born into Pacifica's Haitian diaspora like Milko, your career options are limited. This talented kid quickly caught the attention of the local Voodoo Boys, who took him under their wing and raised him as a professional netrunner.\n\nA moving story? Not really. Gangs aren't charities and their protection comes at a price. In Milko's case, that price is chronic insomnia caused by remorse.
Come by the arcade, V! got something sweet to thank you for a job well done.
Knew I could count on you, V. Trial's over, Eric's out, and our involvement remains a secret. Solved my problem. For good, I hope.

Perhaps I didn't make myself clear. In the future, remember one little rule: the client is always right. If you'd like to take the moral high ground, please do so on your own time and with your own money. I trust that's clear enough. Your gig is complete.

As always, I appreciate the professionalism, V. In your line of business, passing judgement is much like passing gas in company – it may offer temporary relief, but people will turn their backs on you soon enough. Your job here is done.
Transfers his memories to external storage disks
Treats his body like a temple, avoids substance abuse
Fashion aficionado, fan of Kerry Eurodyne's style
Spent 5 years in La Santé prison, VIP wing
Ties to criminal underworld in France, where she has a bounty on her head
Ahem… Word is the boys over Santo recently confiscated some generators… ;)
I think I got just the thing…
Jump out of sewer to the ground.

Yo chooms, we got a real shitwreck outside the Scraper. Corp convoy's trashed, congratz, but clean your shit up. Get the goods up to container 21 & 29. You find any prem iron, haul that shit to the armory near the elevator.\n\n This week's code is 2045.
But we're chill. We set things right and u get back that preem ride u jacked. Sound good?
I'll be watchin in rea SHIT HOLD ON MY PIZZAS HERE
so keep ur eyes glued here, i'll be sendin u tips. Just remember - once ur in, ain't no goin back -- gonna cut off the elevator to keep any surprises from showin up
Don't celebrate yet. Could still spot u so stay alert

The chief and only surgeon at the Haven clinic on Montaña de Oro Ave. It's not clear how he learned his trade or where he worked before, but the unbroken composure he maintains in any situation would suggest a field hospital after a bloody, hopeless battle.\n\nEmpathy is not Anderson's strong point, but it'd be wrong to consider him devoid of feeling. The very fact that he has chosen to devote his skills to serving the poorest residents of Dogtown speaks volumes. Which begs the question... why?

Bill is the epitome of mediocrity. He has mediocre dreams, mediocre needs and his overall life is pretty, well... mediocre. His attempts to break out of mediocrity are plain to see. He joined the NCPD because a friend said he should and Bill never learned how to say "No." Bill's mediocrity turned out to be exactly what the NCPD was looking for.\nAt work, Bill met his love, muse and confidant - Stella. Occasionally, they manage to time their shifts so that they can spend an evening together in their small unit in a megablock. Bill then looks at Stella and ponders, "Am I good enough for her?"

A sharpshooter from an elite SovOil unit with one hundred and sixty-seven confirmed kills, visual implants in full synchronization with Smart Link, quickened reflexes, adrenaline pumps, II-tier netrunner training and camouflage software.\n\nBoris Ribakov is a retired spec ops veteran, man of action and killing machine for whom there will never be a shortage of work in Dogtown.

Some people genuinely believe others are good. They trust them. They lend them money and their priced possessions. They don't think about whether they deserve it. They sacrifice their time without expecting anything in return. Briana Dolson is one such person, but only to those she considers her own - the residents of Longshore Stacks. Strangers are suspicious at best\n\nBriana rose to the top of her community in the Stacks when solving other people's problems became her daily life. Need protein blocks? You go to Briana. Child gone missing? You go to Briana. Was your brother killed? Briana. You can be sure that she'll listen to you and do everything she can to help. Of course, Briana is not a flawless. If she were, she wouldn't have ended up in Dogtown.

If you want to escape your past, you go to Night City. If the past catches up with you there, you flee to the Badlands. If you have several pasts and each of them wants you dead, then you hop over to Dogtown and pray Hansen likes you. Dodger's prayers were answered. Carl "Dodger" Robinson started working for BARGHEST and bringing in big money in the best way he knew - dealing drugs. And what about Dodger's pasts? One is the NCPD and three life sentences, another is gravely insulting a prominent Tyger Claws boss, and the third is a group of nomads robbed of several million eddies. Everyone knows, however, that Hansen's people can't be touched. Not in Dogtown.

The world isn't fair. Those who hold power abuse it; the law favors the rich; the poor get poorer; the rich get richer and so on. While you're busy arguing whether that's a cynical or objective view of the world, NCPD officer Charles Wilson is stopping cars in Watson and extorting bribes. This is a man who has learned that life rewards those who take shortcuts - a piece of knowledge he uses on a daily basis.

Fiona Vargas is extremely talented and moderately cynical, at least by Dogtown standards. She quickly became a respected ripper in the community, and just as quickly she was faced with a choice - either stay at the hospital and treat patients, or start cybermodifying athletes. Help people, or make money. After a few years, she became the head of the Center for Neuromotor Development, Site 341, and her office accumulated medals, trophies and awards won by the outstanding athletes she helped mould.\n\nThere is, however, no success without failure. Some kids don't succeed and their files end up in a drawer in Fiona's desk - and there they stay, buried along with their dreams. Today, Dr. Fiona Vargas' main job is to divide people into two types - those who will bring her medals, and those who belong in the drawer.

A prosecutor with fifteen years of experience under her belt and the bane of gangers from Northside all the way to Pacifica. She has established her reputation on a ruthless adherence to one simple rule: there is no escaping justice. The media love her because she always has a juicy statement and her superiors give her promotion after promotion as her conviction rate shoots through the roof.\n\nYet some claim there's more to Georgina than meets the eye - namely her shady dealings with the underworld and her selective understanding of justice. Whenever the law doesn't suit her aims, she bends it. To get what you want in Night City, sometimes you have to strike a deal with the devil. Georgina has him on speed-dial.

A Zetatech engineer who thought he had caught his big break after landing a corporate position, though in reality it turned out to be Zetatech who ha caught him by the balls. His knack for problem-solving made him a competent engineer and an even better grifter. His intelligence, diluted by clumsiness, means he usually has more luck than sense, but by some miracle he always lands on his feet.

Born in Leningrad in 2034, she was recruited by SovOil agents while studying at the Leningrad Sanitary-Hygiene Medical Institute, with a specialization in anesthetics. According to a character profile drawn up by the SovOil Security Bureau, she is "a cunning, intelligent and shrewd individual with no interest in ideological matters, fond of money and her profession."\n\nIt is hard to argue with this assessment. For years, Katya followed orders to the letter, deploying her knowledge during interrogations, making sure her interlocutors' conditions didn't reach critical levels too soon, listening and analyzing every word they uttered. She has an excellent memory and the things she hears can prove very valuable - and not only to her employers.

If insecurity is the fuel for pathological ambition and toxic relationships, then Leon Rinder drove his entire life on a full tank. Dysfunctional families and rough upbringings affect some more than others, but in Rinder's case he was shaped by it. Underappreciated, unloved, inadequate. A boy raised by the streets. It was there that he began to mask his fear and bashfulness with violence and aggression. He fought and won without mercy and without any respect for human life. The streets were forced to adopt him.\n\nSometimes a guide or mentor appears on the paths of frightened, fragile men; someone who sees something in them and offers a chance at a second life. Rinder's neighborhood evidently lacked boxing coaches or charismatic preachers... instead, there was a Militech recruitment agency. Rinder was willing to sacrifice anything for the army and in turn Militech showered him with medals. The young, overly-zealous youth finally caught the attention of one Kurt Hansen. From that moment on, Rinder truly felt important.

Michael clung to various jobs, but jobs somehow never really clung to Michael. Years ago, when he landed a job repairing Militech AVs, he thought his Californian dream would finally come true. The come-down was painful: a mistake resulting in a crash, compensation for a paralyzed corpo who survived the accident, disciplinary action. Things went from bad to worse: he moved to Heywood, opened an auto repair shop and fell into bankruptcy. Then it was odd jobs here and there - cleaning megablocks and guarding parking lots with episodes of alcoholic haze in between.\n\nWhen his wife finally decided she'd had enough, took their son and left, Michael decided to start fresh. He scammed a friend out of a loan, fled to Dogtown and opened a slot machine parlor. This time things will work out... right?

As a member of the scavs in Dogtown, her comrades hold her in high regard. Why? Unlike them, she has something she really cares about – family.

Despite Nika and Gaspar being twins, she takes care of her brother like a caring older sister. When Gaspar became addicted to immunosuppressants, Nika blamed herself. Before she could force him to go into rehab, he vanished in Dogtown.

One last lead pointed Nika to Anthony Anderson's clinic on Montaña de Oro Ave.

When Stella was a little girl, she dreamed of becoming a rock star. When she grew up, she tried to get hired at Militech. When she realized that pursuing dreams is the stuff of BDs, she became a police officer. Every day she risks her life to help those who don't appreciate it and gets in the way of people who have a good memory for faces. She re-ups her cortisol blockers once every two months and would do it more often were it not for her NCPD paycheck just about covering her rent.\nShe met Bill at a police precinct and though it wasn't love at first sight, it gradually grew. It started with sharing rent, followed by the impossible: vacations, a bigger apartment and corporate health care. Eventually Bill proposed and Stella accepted, though not at first. She still owns a large collection of braindances.

Formerly a Catholic priest, now a "spiritual advisor" to patients at the Haven clinic in Dogtown. An idealist, but also a man who isn't afraid to face the truth - when the pews at his congregation began gathering dust, he chose to act. Instead of closing the church's doors to "unbelievers", i.e. Dogtown newcomers looking for a roof over their heads, Odell opened them even wider.\n\nWith the help of Anthony Anderson, a surgeon with a mysterious past, they set up a clinic for the most needy, poorest residents. If constant exposure to the clinic's hopelessness hasn't led Odell to a crisis of faith, it either means he never truly believed in God, or that he's a saint.

Steven Santos is a patriot willing to sacrifice much for his country. Perhaps not his life, but at the very least his self-respect. As a risk assessment specialist in Brazil's intelligence service, he not only knows when a mission is in jeopardy, but when to look the other way and keep things under wraps. What more could you want from a loyal subordinate?\n\nSantos faces any distasteful or righteous decisions with reluctance and well-known cliches like "If I don't do it, someone else will", or "That's just how the system works." But when Santos' conscience gets too murky, he makes an effort to clean it up. Just not too clean.

When Tommie sat in his room filled with posters of famous athletes, he was just another kid living in a west coast slum. When he got into the Center for Neuromotor Development in Dogtown, he was convinced he'd finally made it big.\n\nWithin a day, dreams of a sports career turned into an achievable goal. And so began the daily examinations, painful trials, surgeries and buckets of sweat poured into training. Tommie felt special. Important. But he wasn't the only child at Fiona Vargas's center, and it soon became apparent there were more talented kids than him. Tommie saw the peak, only he'd never reach the top.

The name of this assassin-for-hire who works for the Cuban cartel has become synonymous with bad news. It is said that every time someone in Havana lights a cigar, Aguilar extinguishes a life somewhere around the globe... all to secure the interests of his employers. In the criminal underworld, he has developed the reputation of the ultimate assassin: ruthless, incorruptible and brutally efficient. Sometimes he also acts as a negotiator, where even his mere presence can cool heated disputes. But should the one-man diplomatic corps routine fail, bodies will begin to drop. As many as necessary.\n\nHis legend has grown to the point that some Valentinos scare their misbehaving children with the warning: "If you don't quiet yourself, Aguilar will." Even if you only believe a fraction of the urban legends tied to him, the infamous assassin would still have dozens of high-profile victims to his name. Whether you're a gang leader, police commissioner, corp exec or politician, when you hear the name Aguilar, you run, you hide and you pray for mercy.

Undercover FIA agent, metanthropic technology specialist and Solomon Reed's ex-protégé. Growing up in the slums of the Los Angeles Metroplex, she saw her parents drown in various addictions, her friends' childhoods plummet into a neverending cycle of crime, an environment riddled with inescapable poverty and a life of hopelessness... but she always dreamed of seeing herself on the braindance billboards. It was a stroke of luck that the BD studio that discovered her was an FIA front.\nSoon, Alex was a fledgling agent under the wing of accomplished spy Solomon Reed, undertaking risky ops and classified missions - both domestic and foreign. When the Unification War broke out, she was sent to Night City, where things went south and Alex came full circle. She returned to the slums she so desperately wanted to leave, though this time it was Dogtown instead of LA. After seven years under cover doing routine spy work, she had almost lost hope of ever getting out of this hellhole... until an old friend suddenly appeared on her doorstep.

The more fiery half of the of the netrunner duo that go by the name of Skylight in cyberspace. Relatively wealthy by birth, formally educated, but perpetually insatiable, she craves adventure, excitement and unusual experiences, which first pushed her to work - then lock horns - with the French criminal organization known as the Collective. Along the way, there was some time done in the VIP wing of "La Santé" prison, work for Militech on the Cynosure project and, of course, the numerous hacking assignments she undertook with her twin brother on the side. Today, however, she's entertaining Kurt Hansen himself. And tomorrow? Maybe one of the fashion shows she so loves to attend? A visit to Tokyo, London, Paris? Or maybe another dangerous assignment for dangerous peeps? Who knows what tomorrow will bring...

The more phlegmatic half of the netrunner duo known as Skylight in cyberspace. An avid meditator, expensive car lover and preacher of what he calls "spiritual hygiene," but also a formally educated software engineer. He offered his services honestly and legally for a time, but very quickly realized that he would rather hack for organized crime and clandestine corporate operations rather than be just another quant for a European agency. The Cynosure project, part of Militech's Night City operations, was one of many assignments Aymeric was involved in, rarely working without his twin sister by his side. He recently returned to the City of Dreams at the personal invitation of Kurt Hansen. If you wanna do biz, do it with the big fish; the bigger, the better.

A heap of muscle and chrome bearing the rank of Lieutenant Colonel in BARGHEST. Bennett was Kurt Hansen's sidekick from the days when they both served in the army, where he stood out for his strength and determination on the battlefield, but also for his lack of discipline and sadism. He avoided jail time for his war crimes only because of Hansen's intervention - and only to him is Bennett unswervingly loyal. When the ashes of war settled over Pacifica in 2070, Bennett emerged as commander of the armed forces of the freshly-formed BARGHEST. He continues in that role to this day, inspiring respect mixed with fear among his subordinates. Obedient to Hansen, he never crosses the line without an explicit order, but his favorite pastime remains hanging people from lampposts.

A media for whom, until recently, writing for screamsheets was her bread and butter. But Bree always wanted something more from life. She finally stumbled across a serious story, and although it got red-hot, she decided not to let it go. Now she's rummaging through corp closets for skeletons - a lucrative commodity in Night City that could either earn you stacks, or more commonly a bullet to the head.\nBree is paranoid and stressed, but that's hardly surprising given the circumstances. She knows what she wants and intends to achieve it regardless of the price. She is secretive and careful with her words - saving them instead for her articles.

Militech's undercover agent, a cyber-cowboy who hunts down individuals who threaten the corporation's interests, often operating under cover. Beneath the face of a cool professional is a man who simply wants to do the right thing. Dante knows it's easy to make a mistake when passing judgment alone, but he also knows it's safer to shoot one time too many than one time too few. He only manages to sleep soundly once the job is done. He doesn't particularly enjoy working for Militech, but every day he gets up, swallows the bitter pill and fits his iron in his holster; he knows that if he lets go, the world - his world - would probably collapse.

Hansen's lieutenant and close comrade from the days of "Midnight Storm" - the operation to occupy Pacifica. Normally a loyal soldier, his reputation has recently taken a hit - he messed up big-time, started making deals behind Kurt's back... Subtlety is not his strong suit - he'd rather shoot all his problems than fix them.\n\nAfter years of serving under Hansen, he's getting increasingly annoyed with being treated as an inferior. Either he proves himself through loyalty and resourcefulness... or through shrewdness and wile. As a gambling man, he couldn't choose anything but the latter.

Most of the files on Kurt Hansen's military past were classifed as top secret following the end of the Unification War. Only top Militech execs and certain members of Congress in Washington have clearance to learn just who this former Colonel truly is. He's the man who secured a foothold for the NUSA in Night City as part of Operation "Midnight Storm". The same man who then, after being abanonded by the NUS government at war's end, built from that foothold a new homeland for himself, all financed by smuggling and arms deals on a global scale.

To some, he's a glorified gangster and war profiteer, to others – a deserter and terrorist. To others still, he's the charismatic leader of BARGHEST, the liberating force that keeps Dogtown free from NCPD jurisdiction and corporate influence and that has turned the derelict district into a new home for so many without one.

Kurt Hansen is a man of many faces. But if you ask Dogtown residents, most will say it's safer to keep your head down than to see any of them for yourself.

Two batshit-crazy twins going on even crazier adventures - the duo Night City viewers deserved, but didn't know they needed. The two sisters' show brings content that would perk up even the most skullsponge-fried BD zombie, with weekly episodes packed to the brim with adrenaline and sheer absurdity.

The one and only Queen Bitch of Dogtown! An aspiring BD star who would pounce at the first chance of making it big. And if someone stands in her way of glory, she'll claw their face off. For now, her BDs are mainly circulating amongst the truly desperate BD junkies of Dogtown, but everyone starts somewhere, right? After all, difficult starts only make for extra drama in one's biography.

For the longest time, Murphy thought the most important thing was to find himself in the right place at the right time at least once - then life would be a breeze. Years spent living in Dogtown shattered this illusion. You had to stick with the right people, often break your back for them. Dogtown is a miniscule nation, but its atmosphere is tense - it needs an iron fist to keep the comers and goers in check. That fist belongs to Murphy. As a representative of Hansen's more approachable side, he'll talk to everyone who's anyone and sound them out. Depending on the need, or Hansen's mood, that talk can go smoothly, or it can end with a bullet in the other person's skull.

The incumbent president of the New United States of America. Myers was born into a wealthy and influential East Coast family, said to be descendants of the first English settlers aboard the Mayflower. She began her political career in the US Marine Corps - her patriotism, courage on the battlefield, obedience and discipline paved the way for her rapid promotion and brought her to the attention of Militech's top brass. After the death of the corporation's CEO, Donald Lundee, it was Myers who succeeded him.

There are conflicting opinions about Myers' reign as president of the corporation, but her reformist zeal has earned her more opponents than supporters. Without waiting for an official vote of no confidence, Myers tendered her honorary resignation as CEO, justifying the decision with her intention to run for the office of the president of NUSA. She won the election, becoming the second - in the brief history of the New States - woman in the Oval Office.

She ended her first term with a bang with the Unification War in 2069 to reunite all the states. Despite military support from Militech, Myers had to withdraw NUSA troops from California. Her shattered expansionist dreams apparently didn't deter Myers in the slightest, nor have they damaged her popularity as she went on to win two subsequent elections and is now gearing up for a fourth term.

Although as a politician Myers appears in her element, those close to her know she misses her time in the marines. That's not to say the NUSA president's life is devoid of excitement - repeated assassination attempts confirm that a dead Myers would be more valuable to some political factions than the status quo. Yet for the time being, the greatest danger to the president's life remains her long-standing nicotine addiction.

Solomon Reed is a sleeper agent of the Federal Intelligence Agency (FIA) and among the best agents in the NUSA's ranks. In his heyday, Reed could compete with legends like Morgan Blackhand, but he was never interested in being a one-time star and collecting medals on his shelf. People like Reed look for something greater than themselves, and he found it by serving his country, no matter how dirty the work.\n\nHis dossier includes thwarted assassination attempts on important figures and successful negotiations with kidnappers, but also blackmail, sabotage operations and coups in South American republics. His last mission: to build a network of spies in Night City during the Unification War. In 2070, when the conflict became a lost cause for the NUSA, Reed's cell was disbanded and he dropped off the radar. Though he no longer reads the morning report with his breakfast, for seven years he has been waiting for a one particular phone call - a call that just came in.

A brilliant Voodoo Boy netrunner who was once the right hand of Maman Brigitte before they clashed over ideals. Brigitte dreamed of piercing the Blackwall, which led to constant skirmishes with NetWatch, while Slider preferred to stay away from grand schemes to focus on what he did best - carrying out corporate heists and assassinations via cyberspace. Unfortunately for him, one such heist caught the attention of FIA agents, who irreversibly deprived him of his sight, and then through blackmail and intimidation made him their informant. In an attempt to break free from the agency's chains, he fled Pacifica and joined his brothers in Dogtown, where he took control of an illegal software operation. As it turned out, the FIA's reach extended there as well.

Song So Mi (Korean -  송소미), codenamed "Songbird", is a netrunner in the FIA. She started out as a freelance netrunner, taking on assignments that others dismissed as well-paying but suicidal. Meanwhile, before So Mi's eyes, corporate data fortresses opened without so much as a shove. She always worked solo and spent every eddie earned on newer, better equipment and ever-more-extravagant means of entertainment. She quickly became a living legend of the trade, although some didn't believe someone of her caliber could exist for long - if at all. The FIA believed.

When Song took an oath of allegiance to the New United States and was given the operational nickname "Songbird," the prototype technologies developed by the agency in strict secrecy from foreign governments - and sometimes from her own - were placed at her fingretips. In return, Songbird was forced to quickly learn two concepts that had been completely foreign to her until that point: following orders and playing as a team.

The immunity of a government agent, backed and protected by a powerful bureaucratic apparatus, guaranteed Song would remain untouchable. From masking vehicle signatures at secret meetings between NUSA officials and military juntas in Central America, to obliterating the digital footprints of commandos that executed terrorists impersonating the Bartmoss collective, NetWatch agents could only listen to the echoes of Songbird's footsteps in cyberspace - echoes that suspiciously went quiet near the Blackwall.

Station wagons rarely elicit a reaction other than a yawn - even from their owners. But not the Alvarado V4FH 570 Herman. Even more trunk capacity comes courtesy of a completely redesigned rear end. Combined with the famous elongated hood of the Alvarado model, Herman has acquired perfectly balanced proportions. The already iconic, now improved dual-torsion axle technology at the car's front can only give one hope that the station wagon will be less prone to failure and cheaper to maintain.\n\nThe fact is, this cruiser is better suited for longer trips than tedious maneuvering on city streets due to its increased weight. So if you urgently need to leave Night City with the whole family, the Alvarado Herman is the car for you.

The interior of the Centurion 1000 is so spacious that its price should be in square feet. No wonder - Chevillon has always specialized in producing extra comfortable limousines that elite politicians and corporate execs like to be chauffered in.\n\nThe car's colossal size requires an equally colossal engine, in this case a CHOOH2 chugger based on the Emperor model, but cranked up to 1,000 horsepower. Those willing to buy a Centurion can choose between single or dual rear axle versions - only who'd want 4x4 when they can have 6x6 drive?

Looks familiar? The 2077 Herrera Riptide GT2 is a faithful copy of the original model prior to the crisis that plunged the Italian carmaker into bankruptcy. Originally, the Riptide was a class-leading luxury sports car. Today, it's even sportier thanks to modern upgrades hidden under its neo-militaristic body, and even more luxurious. After all, this contemporary remake can only be bought by the brand's regular customer - those who purchased a Herrera Outlaw before. Thanks to clever marketing, both models are disappearing from showrooms with a speed comparable to that of the Riptide GT2 on the road. In other words - fast.

BARGHEST engineers treated the original Thorton Colby as a loose inspiration. They transformed the versatile car that millions of Americans have come to love into a paramilitary vehicle for special tasks, such as the ballistic steel panels incorporated into the design that can withstand regular machine gun fire.\n\nThe real secret of this car is its modified suspension, which guarantees the Colby BARGHEST confident handling in the most unpredictable situation or terrain. The tuned tires don't slip off the rim even when punctured, and the armored fuel tank is essentially bulletproof. CrystalDome technology allows for the discreet transport of "dubious" people and goods and the 280 horsepower engine allows for a smooth exit out of any danger zone. If it was possible to order a cab in Dogtown, everyone would want a vehicle like the Thorton Colby BARGHEST to come pick them up.

BARGHEST modded this van to the point of unrecognition, even to Mahir factory specialists. But necessity is the mother of invention, and even the Supron's designers' worst nightmares couldn't compare to Dogtown's roads. Potholes are one thing, but passersby armed to the teeth, landmines and improvised barricades are an altogether different can of worms. The model's facelift included pneumatic suspension, a 349 horsepower engine and armor impenetrable to most bullets and improvised explosive devices. The motto, "necessity over style" was perfectly embodied in the Supron BARGHEST's finesse-free body, but some things are important and others... important-er. Like surviving your next patrol through Dogtown.

This Makigai model looks best when covered in grime, so don't leave it catching dust in a garage. Its relatively small size allows the Tanishi to weave through Dogtown's car wrecks with ease, and the spring suspension and four-wheel drive add spice to every off-road adventure. Even a river of toxic sewage won't be able to shake you off the road - a solid ABS snorkel will keep that putrid water well away from the engine. Small, yet feisty - the Makigai Tanishi in a nutshell.

The Chimera is a prototype tank designed for combat in difficult terrain, including urban areas. It was developed under the leadership of Militech armored division chief engineer Dr. Filippo Andrews. The project was created in response to the need for a "new heavy tank capable of sustained fire and prolonged engagement of enemy forces".

The design of the Chimera tank was developed between 2065 and 2069. The standard loadout includes a KL-274XYA flechette cannon, a PAN-12 Furia laser cannon, a GD27-Angstschema launcher with both surface-to-surface and surface-to-air capability (SSM/SAM), a combat gas atomizer, smoke screens and a sophisticated ICE cyberdefense system (TYA-12) to neutralize enemy netrunner hacks.

Although about thirteen Chimera units were produced, it never entered mass production. According to engineers from the rival Arasaka corporation, the Chimera wouldn't have proved a worthwhile investment due to the unit's apparent "vulnerability to attacks from above, hindering its performance in the urban arena for which it was designed."

The PAN-12 Furia laser cannon was designed to neutralize heavily armored ground and air targets. The cannon is capable of two modes:
1. Burst fire - short beams of plasma capable of causing temporary electrical disruption to hostiles;
2. Continuous fire - a powerful, high-energy beam capable of cutting through the latest in corporate armor technology.

The KL-274XYA flechette cannot is a fast-firing heavy turret (4,800 rounds per minute) that is most effective against organic and lightly armored units. The flechettes can also contain incendiary and explosive elements and the cannon is integrated with a thermal targeting system.

The Chimera's six legs provide excellent mobility and versatility in urban terrain, capable of climbing inclines of up to 87 degrees. The legs are reinforced with advanced ERA (explosive reactive armor), but should its legs sustain critical damage, it can still maintain near full mobility with only four. Each leg is also equipped with kinetic energy absorbers and energy recovery systems. Every step it takes generates approximately 31,000 Newtons of force.

Militech may not be your first or second choice when it comes to car makers, but their armored vehicles are unparalleled. The Hellhound has been spiked with the corp's state-of-the-art technology like a needle-ridden voodoo doll. Getting inside this SUV feels like being inside an AV - getting out, too, as the side-sliding doors let you feel like you're exiting an AV mid-flight. A real military kick comes from the Hellhound's two gun ports, with the option of mounting a full-size turret or a missile launcher. The armored body is just the icing on the cake of a truly indestructible chassis, which dissipates explosive energy in the event of driving over a mine, and six impenetrable tires. The Hellhound's windshields are bulletproof armor-plated with screens affixed on the inside – the latest in CrystalDome technology. Your enemy never knows how many people are inside, whereas you can see the outside clear as day. When descending into the pits of hell, this beast truly is man's best friend.

The Mizutani is the true definition of a sports car - fast, responsive and aggressive. The sight of the Shion's hood was the last sight of many a careless pedestrian on the streets of Night City. The Mizutani's latest edition, the Hozuki, aims to spruce up the brand's image. The hatchback body and four seats are meant to be an incentive for parents and families to give this car a shot. But Mizutani wouldn't be itself if it didn't equip this seemingly family-oriented car with a 180-horsepower hybrid engine and adaptive suspension for quick cornering. Tell your kids to buckle up, then slam that pedal.

"Quadra" is a word that many sports car enthusiasts have tattooed on their chests and close to their hearts. The Sport R-7 was developed in the 2060s as an homage to fans of classic muscle cars. This car is both beefy and sculpted - its heavy neo-militaristic body moves around on a 480-horsepower engine and rear-wheel drive. Compared to the Quadra V-Tech, the R-7 model is less responsive, which is not to say slow, but is more spacious in exchange. The increased stability also makes it more approachable for less seasoned drivers - no need to fear breaking the world record of zero to a hundred when the light turns green.

The SV I-12 Coda I has been the mainstay of Space Force One in recent years. Compared to the Griffin 414 President Kress flew on back in her day, this model is much lighter and faster. Based on Songbird's recommendations, Rosalind Myers put forward a number of requirements that the Coda had to meet in addition to the general safety standards for suborbital aircraft, and these are what probably led to so few casualties when SFO crashed in Dogtown. Above all, the reduction of the sizeable office area made it possible to comfortably accommodate the same number of NUSA agents as in a larger craft, while the office itself was reinforced with prototype shock-dampening fibers made by Militech. Last but not least, this is the first presidential aircraft equipped with combat bots and the first to have ever activated them.

If you ever dreamed of riding in a tank, the Merrimac MSL3 will make that dream come true! Sort of. Thorton is known for delivering on carrying capacity, but other models are like packs of chewing gum compared to the Merrimac. The increased rear load capacity achieved by two of the three axles allows loading equipment fit for a small army in the trunk. In addition, the Merrimac's reinforced body helps protect passengers from light — which is not to say harmless — gunfire. Thorton's standard hydropneumatic suspension, combined with six beefy wheels, gives the Merrimac MSL3 the green light to roll over any terrain.

If Villefort ever needed to be advertised, it might use "less is more" as a slogan to promote its coupé model. But Villefort is a household name across every state for its tasteful design, excellent performance and almost obscene driving comfort.\n\nThe V400 Coupé is a compact, two-door limousine, designed and manufactured for customers who rarely ride with anyone but themselves - not including their egos. Lastly, the impressive 390 horsepower engine and rear-wheel drive are an excellent trade-off for the car's reduced proportions.

The ideal choice for those who want to do some shootin' 'n executin'. After firing a quick salvo at an enemy, it feels great to run up and tenderize them with a meat mallet installed around the barrel of the gun. Anyone claiming this addition to be unnecessary has clearly never used it before. It's also suitable as a portable battering ram.

Produced from an amalgamation of various Militech weapon parts by Hansen Armory. The ideal compromise between quality and price - a weapon that won't fail during a firefight, nor drain your wallet.\n\nIts short, compact barrel allows you to fire a quick and deadly salvo from the hip, while the long magazine lends the gun a balanced feel. With the HA-4 Grit, you can confidently leap into action.

A surprisingly unique firearm clearly inspired by Arasaka's Shingen. Its powerful rapid fire comes with a heavy recoil, but eventually you'll find a mutual rhythm to your shots. Could this gun be the one you've been looking for all your life? Many would say so, despite the initial negative attitude towards its crude appearance. But what starts out as an oddity often ends up becoming a classic - especially when it's effective, and when it comes to the HA-7 Warden, there's no debate. You're sure to create many beautiful memories together.

The shape resembles Paleolithic knives made from splintered bones. Perfect for both wood carving and… flaying. Crude, yet devilishly dangerous - the perfect weapon in the hands of a skilled combatant.

A prototype model based one of Militech's smart automatic rifles. What more could you want from a weapon spitting homing rounds without needing a Smart Link? Poison rounds, obviously. To turn an enemy into Swiss cheese is child's play, but to turn them into a bullet-ridden, steaming pile of liquified remains... that's a job for Hercules 3AX. 10/10 for style, 2/10 eco-for friendliness.

Haters will say it looks antique, connoiseurs will claim it's a classic. Thanks to its simple construction, it rarely jams and is unlikely to fail you when you need it most. Its compact size guarantees it can remain hidden when tucked away behind your belt, which frankly makes it the ideal ally in heated arguments or when uninvited guests come knocking on your door.\nThe best thing about it? It just works.

A large-caliber, well-balanced rifle coveted by pros and wannabes alike. This hardware sells for top-shelf prices, but because it's a weapon of choice within multiple agencies, there's little doubt it's worth every enny. Once you get your hands on one, everything else will feel like clunky scrap metal by comparison.

Cheap, ugly, but effective. If you're given a choice between a Metel and nothing at all, it may seem like a tough decision, but the Metel is the right call. It's most popular in slums and amongst those who put their faith in their skills, not their hardware. It can inflict some serious damage in the right hands, so if you like challenges and have a fondness for junk, this revolver from Techtronika is for you.

The skies above Dogtown never sleep. Every now and then, AVs fly into its airspace and drop gifts for BARGHEST. Who sends the airdrops to Dogtown? It's a mystery. What's in the airdrops? Also a mystery. Want to unravel it? Take a look inside and try to survive.

If you hear "Dogtown" and automatically think "BARGHEST," chances are you won't die straight away. The organization founded by Kurt Hansen is more than just an ordinary Night City gang. No one else has managed the feat of carving an entire district out for themselves, kicking out the police completely and keeping it that way for nearly a decade.
It started small: Colonel Hansen's unit seized part of Pacifica at the end of the Unification War and never laid down arms. Only six soldiers remain from that squad, and as Hansen's most trusted men they now sit at the top of the food chain. The nascent BARGHEST quickly took similar folks under its wing: veterans who'd been forgotten by the megacorps, mercs without contracts, renegade gangers from various parts of the city - you name it.

Hansen's organization also proved tempting to average Night City residents who, for various reasons, found themselves at the end of their ropes. Kurt Hansen gave them a gun, a salary, medical care via his ripper contacts and - perhaps most importantly - asked no questions in exchange for their absolute loyalty. For those at the very bottom, BARGHEST is a pretty good alternative to a life of petty crime - a career with a short life expectancy.
Anywhere else, under different leadership, the band of delinquents that make up BARGHEST would have collapsed like a house of cards or atrophied like a cyberpsycho's brain. Hansen managed the impossible. Credit goes to his dominating presence, charisma and intelligence, but most of all presenting folks with a fresh start - one without hidden costs or corporate fine print, and a place where cops and undercover narcs get strung up from lampposts. For many, this vision was, is and will continue to be extremely tempting.

In 2013, an enterprising central european immigrant couple, Franz and Tonya Yanovsky, founded the family construction and renovation company Pol-Bud in Sacramento. Thanks to its competitive pricing and low-cost labor, as well as an economic boost after the Fourth Corporate War, the company's revenue grew steadily. The opening of its own cement factory in 2030 sealed Pol-Bud's status as a leader in the construction industry.
In 2048, the corporation's new CEO, Yan Yanovsky (Franz's oldest son), decided to rename the company Corp-Bud and make it independent of the global supply chain. By investing in his own fleet of dredge ships, he ensured Corp-Bud's continued access to the most valuable raw materials in the construction sector - sand.
Since then, the Corp-Bud logo has become a common sight in the North American landscape. While the corporation was building highways, shipyards, bridges and skyscrapers at an express pace, the ships sucking in hundreds of thousands of tons of sand gradually helped change the direction of ocean currents. When Mexico's Guadalupe Island vanished underwater as a result, Corp-Bud's good fortune came to an end.
Today the corporation is facing huge image and financial problems. The multibillion-dollar compensation it must pay to refugees from flooded areas is only a drop in the ocean of the developer's problems. Indeed, the North American Environmental Protection Agency has threatened to sink the corporation's fleet if Corp-Bud does not stop the predatory extraction of sand from the Pacific seabed.

An anti-corporate organization focused on fighting Biotechnica. Initially, it comprised mostly farmers and agricultural entrepreneurs in North America. Members of Crimson Harvest demanded Biotechnica cease charging annual fees for crop licenses, an extortion scheme that was depleting the budgets of small farms and forcing farmers to sell off their land, tranche by tranche, to the corporation.
In response to peaceful protests, Biotechnica not only increased its prices, but also, if the rumors are to be believed, unleashed a virus that decimated all crops grown from grain not sourced from its corporate labs.
The helpless farmers filled the ranks of Crimson Harvest en masse and as the organization grew, they began protesting in an acceleratingly radical manner. Biotechnica employees regularly fell victim to assaults, beatings or even murder; the bloodiest incident occurred in a research facility in Paris. In its aftermath, being a member of Crimson Harvest was outlawed by the authorities of all American countries and was officially recognized as a terrorist organization.
Some existing supporters of Crimson Harvest - unnerved by the violent and downright cruel direction the organization has taken - packed up and left. Their place was soon taken over by anti-corporate fanatics, for whom fighting for farmer's rights became an excuse to burn, kill and sew mayhem. Despite Biotechnica's efforts, most Crimson Harvest members remain elusive and at large.

The Federal Intelligence Agency was established in 2006 after the dissolution of the NSA (National Security Agency) and the CIA (Central Intelligence Agency), both of which were implicated in organizing a conspiracy to overthrow the US government. In theory, it was supposed to take over and join their functions, but in practice it remained an underfunded institution of marginal importance for almost half a century.

This all changed after the ratification of the NUSA Constitution in 2053. The FIA was granted extensive powers and privileges, and a huge budget made it possible to recruit a veritable army of secret informants and equip them with state-of-the-art technology. Since 2065 when Rosalind Myers became the NUS president, the FIA has steadily grown in strength. The active participation of agents in the course of the Unification War has become an open secret. After the war ended, the FIA's involvement in direct military action was greatly reduced in favor of data acquisition and analysis.

FIA agents now conduct intelligence operations around the world, loyally and discreetly pursuing the NUSA's political objectives. The weekly reports that President Myers receives from the FIA's leadership provide her with invaluable knowledge of the plans and actions of foreign governments and multinational corporations, and even a few influential private individuals. Skeptics say that the FIA serves Myers mainly as a secret weapon in her political games against Militech. The reality? Only the FIA knows.

The loudspeakers appeared in Dogtown in the first weeks after the war as the freshly-bombarded neighborhood was rising from the rubble. While chaos ruled the streets, Kurt Hansen looked for a way to quickly regroup and organize. When his soldiers found an abandoned radio station in one of the ruined buildings, the problem solved itself. From then on, every day in Dogtown began and ended with a broadcasted speech, informing residents of new directives, orders and reconstruction progress.\nThe solution, meant to be initially temporary, worked so well that the loudspeakers remain in the neighborhood to this day, emitting words from their leader, Colonel Kurt Hansen. "Kurt FM" - as it is jokingly called by residents - can also be caught on shortwave. On it, one an hear announcements about generator deliveries to to the hospital, Hansen's soldierly reminiscing on the anniversary of Dogtown's occupation, and when the colonel is in a particularly good mood - Balkan folk hits. And even if some might cringe as they listen, it's hard to deny that BARGHEST's broadcasting is part of the neighborhood's identity.

The official beginning of the New United States of America is marked by the ratification of the country's constitution, which took place on July 4, 2053. It was then that Elisabeth Kress, having ruled the country for 35 years, handed over power to an interim government in preparation for elections. Rosalind Myers was the third person in the presidential seat and also the second woman to hold the post. She began her first term in office by presenting a unification program to fulfill the age-old ambition of the federalist NUSA government - to reunite all the states. The separatist territories were, of course, reluctant to return under the star-spangled banner, which led to the outbreak of the Unification War in 2069. The conflict ended with the signing of the Treaty of Unification, which guaranteed that the Free States would retain their autonomy on the condition that they join the new federal government.\n\nThe center of NUSA power resides in the megacities to the northeast of the country, referred to collectively as the Plex and covering areas from Boston in the north to Washington in the south. President Rosalind Myers' third - which doesn't mean last - term in office is now coming to an end. Although the country's official political system remains a democracy, the continued dominance of one party (the Federalist Party) since the 2050s and strict national security restrictions make NUSA more like an authoritarian-run police state in reality.

Orbital Air was founded in Nairobi, Kenya, at the beginning of the 21st century - it is the oldest corporation specializing in the transportation of cargo and passengers via the Earth's orbit. OA's fleet consists of heavy-lift rockets, manned and unmanned spacecraft and commercial passenger shuttles. The Kenyan giant controls most of the world's spaceports, including the largest cosmodrome in Mogadishu.
Orbital Air's extensive portfolio of services additionally includes the construction and maintenance of orbital stations and satellite networks. The corporation also operates points of so-called "rocketless spaceships", using electromagnetic catapults (mass drivers). Because of this, Orbital Air has managed to significantly reduce the cost of launching cargo into low Earth orbit and secure a dominant position in the space industry.
Orbital Air remains the undisputed leader in innovative orbital technologies. Under its current CEO, Leslie Wawuda, the corporation pours immeasurable resources into space exploration/conquest. Currently, in cooperation with the New African authorities, the corporation is conducting research on the Alpha Centauri system.
Orbital Air's main competitors are the European Space Council (ESC), which established the first city on the moon, Tycho, in 1997; they also frequently collaborated with Night Corporation.
Indeed, Orbital Air and Miriam Night's corporation weren't always at each other's throats. The cold war between the two colossi began around 2045 when the Kenyan corp took over a mass driver build site in Night City, which was left unfinished. As a result, Night Corp irrevocably lost the chance to have their home city be the frontier for conquering the great beyond of space.

Dogtown scavs are much better organized and equipped than their Night City brethren. They're no longer a Pan-Slavic horde of itchy triggers looking for a quick-'n'-dirty brawl, a strong stim and an easy eurobuck. Rumor has it those ones in Dogtown are linked to Soviet intelligence. True or false? Hard to tell. What's known is that whoever is spreading these rumors runs the risk of getting their picture stapled to the Memorial Tree in the Stacks.\n\nThe Dogtown scavs have cash, good equipment and a bit of disdain for their poorer NC kind. Why? Because only those without a knack for business end up in Night City. The scav oligarchy secures business in Hansen's backyard. So why would Hansen tolerate them? Simple. It's all about the money.

The largest and wealthiest Soviet corporation with an iron grip on the petrochemical industry. SovOil has been using its vast resources to manipulate the Soviet government for decades. There is no shortage of claims that SovOil holds the real power in the USSR. The corporation operates worldwide, but its main markets are Europe and Asia. It is less popular in North America, though it has branches in Washington and Night City. SovOil continues to focus mainly on oil production and sales, but is also becoming increasingly bolder in the CHOOH2 and experimental fuels markets.

Some say the Voodoo Boys of Dogtown live closer to the "edge" than their brothers and sisters in Pacifica. They take more risks and rarely look back, explore the dark corners of the net more often and end up earning more, too. In a way, the boundary between Pacifica and Dogtown is also the boundary between idealists and pragmatists.\n\nPragmatic Dogtown netrunners do business in the Stadium, lend others their services, run shady biz and protect the data of Hansen's guests, covering their tracks through the district's subnets. In other words, they keep the deluge of ones and zeros leaking out from Dogtown. From time to time, this symbiotic relationship between BARGHEST and the Voodoo Boys can seem shaky. So far, however, Hansen managed to ensure it's a little rumble here and there and not a full-blown earthquake.

A pavilion in Terra Cognita technology park dedicated to extraplanetary travel. The exhibit offered a range of information, tips and anecdotes that might be useful to would-be travelers as well as lectures about this ever-evolving industry. Many educational activities were geared toward younger people, including the opportunity to talk with recruiters from corporations involved in aerospace technology, engineering and exploration.\n\nToday, all that remains of the exhibit is a lone shuttle. Most everything else has been stripped for salvage and sold off by Dogtown's inhabitants.

An abandoned pavilion in the Terra Cognita technology park dedicated to nature, consisting of several multilevel greenhouses. The exhibits here showcased large specimens of non-indigenous flora cultivated in artificial microclimates as well as several reptile species on the verge of extinction. The real crowdpleaser, however, would be the dinosaur skeletons with holographic reconstructions of tissue projected directly onto the fossilized bones. Over the years, this technologically ambitious enerprise and time capsule for nature's splendor has become overgrown with vegetation... All the more reason to visit, perhaps?

The Scraper is what remains of one of the last investments before the district's closure. This immense structure, located far from the skyline of City Center, was supposed to offer a relaxing, yet luxurious getaway for Night City's rich – though, not necessarily the filthy rich. According to an investor's brochure, the Scraper was designed to be a "modern, 4-star hotel complex located on the picturesque Pacific coast, offering over 250 suites with breathtaking vistas and fitted with the latest in stylish amenities." Of course, those plans clearly failed to materialize.\n\nToday, scavengers have moved in and brought their own decor with them. Stolen tech and cyberware have replaced chic coffee tables. And in place of plush loveseats, they've installed cozy cages for their long-stay "guests".

The Nighthawks Rehabilitation Center was intended to serve the players of the city's dream football team – their health, fitness and (perhaps most importantly) the condition of their advanced cyberware. Investors spared no expense on state-of-the-art equipment for "groundbreaking" (translates to: highly illegal) surgeries. They also hired a staff of biomedical specialists, from ripperdocs and sports physiologists, to sleep specialists, nutrition strategists and acupuncture experts.\n\nThe whole investment quickly fell through, however. The Nighthawks only managed to play only a few games before the team was dissolved, along with any hope of revitalizing Pacifica. It wasn't until the district came under Kurt Hansen's rule that the lights at the former Rehabilitation Center turned back on and stayed on. Perhaps, there's a certain irony here – the place where people were supposed to heal is now a factory for instruments of death, both for BARGHEST itself and for outside buyers. One thing, however, has not changed – no one here fears the law.

The Holy Haven Catholic Church was built with donations from the pockets of Night City's wealthy Catholics at a time when South Pacifica was set to once again become home to the city's affluent. Although the church construction was completed, an exodus of investors buried any hope of repopulating the neighborhood.

It wasn't until Kurt Hansen seized control of Dogtown that the church's pews began to fill. Down-on-their-luck outlaws prayed here for a better tomorrow and sought forgiveness for the sins that had forced them to seek refuge behind Dogtown's walls. But when a better tomorrow never came, and new sins erased memories of the old, the ranks of the faithful began to wither.

The parish's most recent pastor, Odell Blanco, helped repurpose the church building to house a clinic for the area's neediest, which he runs together with ripperdoc and physician Anthony Anderson. Although the scope and quality of medical care here leave much to be desired, Haven Clinic remains the only hope for many of Dogtown's destitute. As Odell might say, "When you have nothing, everything is a gift."

Halsey, Ferris & Skiv began the construction of this colossus in 2061, intending to erect Night City's most impressive hotel to date. However, along with the rest of Pacifica's redevelopment, the project took a fatal nosedive. Following the end of the Unification War, Kurt Hansen laid claim to the half-finished hotel as his new base of operations. Today, the Black Sapphire serves as the shining star around which all of Dogtown revolves.

It stands ninety-nine stories tall with a luxury club, casino and AV landing pads at the top. The ground floor contains warehouses and barracks for BARGHEST soldiers. Everything in between remains a matter of speculation - a prison for VIPs held for ransom, a zoo for endangered animals that Hansen serves to dinner guests at lavish parties, a server room that puts Arasaka Tower's to shame...

It's no surprise the rumors that circle the Black Sapphire grow more and more farfetched every year. Yet one fact is undeniable – the Black Sapphire is Hansen's pride and joy. It is an impenetrable fortress, a palace where he can play King of Dogtown and host dignitaries from the world over, but especially the who's who of Night City's political and criminal landscape.

Officially, very little is known about Project Cynosure. Unofficially? Even less. Putting together the scraps of available information, flimsy hypotheses and conspiracy theories, Project "Cynosure" appears to be Militech's prematurely terminated, secret military research project.\n"Project Cynosure" was Militech's attempt in the second decade of the 21st century to develop an experimental weapon, or tool, to support Militech netrunners venturing into the deepest regions of cyberspace to capture and tame so-called "rogue AIs." These AIs were then to be used in a secret facility located somewhere beneath Pacifica. To what end? Most likely to enhance Militech's military and intelligence capabilities, or perhaps for something even more serious: a competitor to Soulkiller, Arasaka's flagship cyber-weapon.\nHad Militech succeeded, it is likely that the geopolitical landscape in the region, and perhaps the entire world, would look very different. Yet for reasons unknown, the creation of the anti-Soulkiller never happened. According to rumors, Project Cynosure was canceled and buried. Some speculate that a series of accidents occurred in the project's laboratories. Others that the Militech-captured AIs broke free from their shackles and took control of the facility. Still other theories suggest that Arasaka or the cyberspace watchdog, NetWatch, caught wind of the project's existence, forcing Militech to cover its tracks to avoid a diplomatic crisis or even war. What's certain is that the truth will likely never be known.

The nation's top military medical complex, named after a former NUS Air Force surgeon-in-chief. Situated in the verdant serenity of a park in Langley, not far from FIA headquarters, it has served NUS presidents and other esteemed officials for many years. The center's state-of-the-art equipment, team of accomplished doctors and its peaceful environs all play a role in its reputation for elite care and the quick recovery time of its patients.

A huge, neon pyramid in the heart of Dogtown. The Heavy Hearts Club was supposed to be a postcard highlight for a revitalized Pacifica, but now it plays home to the largest nightclub in Kurt Hansen's domain. The deals with the highest stakes are struck under Hansen's watchful eye in the Black Sapphire or the stadium. Everything else is settled here.

The Heavy Hearts has established itself as the go-to meeting place where important players can discuss side deals during their stay in Dogtown. Maybe you ordered a dozen tanks from Hansen at the stadium, but you'd like to land a ultra-rare Rayfield before leaving Night City. Maybe you're in town to have Kurt smuggle a dozen crates of assault rifles into Myanmar, but there's also a shipment of contraband Zetatech cyberware burning a hole in your pocket. In such cases, be sure to make a stop at the Heavy Hearts before going on your merry way.

Of course, maybe you're not a corpo, politician or dirty cop looking to make a deal at all. Maybe you just want to dance the night away without worry of waking up dead in a ditch the next morning. The Heavy Hearts Club has it all.

Night City International and Translunar Spaceport (NCX) is Orbital Air's flagship investment in North America. It was built between 2045 and 2047 where the majestic Morro Rock volcanic neck, a geological feature sacred to local Native American tribes, had stood for 23 million years. But it wasn't heartless corpos who gave permission to demolish the rock – Night City authorities did.

In consultation with a group of investors, the Mayor of Night City agreed to sign a contract to construct a mass driver at the site. Orbital Air management was understandably skeptical that rocket-free launches could successfully take place without corporate backing to ensure its profitability. Therefore, the aerospace megacorp proposed buying up the surrounding land and sprearheading further investment, offering to build a civilian spaceport in the process.

Orbital Air only partially fulfilled the deal, however. By taking advantage of several legal loopholes, the corp cancelled a provision in the arrangement for completing the mass driver's construction. Its rusted, incomplete remains were then eventually dismantled, and OA's monopoly on space colonization remained intact.

Night City International and Translunar Spaceport handles more than 100 million passengers a year and contains three terminals. Terminal A is home to OA TerraLines, a relatively low-cost airline that provides low-orbit transportation services around the globe. Terminal B houses the slightly more expensive OA Tycho and Crystal Palace Direct lines, hauling travelers to the largest lunar city and the famous space station, respectively. Terminal C, on the other hand, is where OA Black and OA HighLines luxury shuttles operate. The purpose and destinations of these flights remain largely unknown, and the cost of that discretion is reflected in the exorbitant ticket prices.

In the heart of Longshore Stacks you'll find a safe haven for any seeking to quench their thirst with a glass of the good stuff and a place to relax with some classic jukebox tunes. Regulars know that the owner and bartender of this establishment are one and the same person. Seven years ago, the woman they know as Daphe laid claim to this vacant building sitting atop an out-of-service boiler room and transformed it into a godsend for the Stacks community – a bar.

To this day, Stacks residents relish visiting the Moth after a rough day, where they're always greeted by a bartender bot or by the owner herself. Daphne's ears are always open to the locals' ramblings and ravings. She has her finger on the pulse of all Dogtown gossip. In fact, if Daphne finds your gossip juicy as all git-out, she might just offer you a round on the house.

In other words, if you're an ennyless Dogtown resident without proper access to a therapist, then you head to Moth, order a stiff drink and talk your heart out to Daphe. It should come as no surprise that this bar never lacks clientele.

Once home to the Night City Nighthawks football team, EBM Petrochem Stadium now hosts a bustling hub for illegal trade. The black market within caters not only to the residents of Dogtown, but also to many of Night City's largest corprorations and most influential players – off the books, of course.\n\nA nuclear-powered aerozep that crashed into the field once upon a time now serves as the primary power source for entire stadium as well as several surrounding buildings.

A residential quarter of Dogtown packed densely with makeshift structures fashioned from shipping containers, old construction equipment and debris. A city within a city that offers everything the average Dogtown resident needs: trade, bars, a central plaza, and even a hotel. Much of the new tech flowing into Hansen's market at the stadium first has its serial numbers filed off here. If you're searching for a missing person, this is the place to start. If all you want is a warm scopburger and a cold beer, go no farther than the Stacks.\n\nKids chase each other in a maze of sheet metal. A local boozehound musician picks at guitar strings. A junkie rubs one out to a skin BD in the comfort of his rusty cargo container. Life finds a way.

In the 2020s Militech established a secret, experimental military project in this part of Pacifica, constructing bunkers and laboratories cleverly hidden beneath urban infrastructure. Nearly half a century later, a group of investors appeared, unaware they were building on the remains of an old military complex. When a lab was excavated at one of the construction sites, the investors were forced out of Pacifica and Militech erected a wall around the neighborhood ostensibly due to gas leaks, poor documentation on local developments and unexploded ordnance from the 4th Corporate War.

In 2077, Dogtown has become a kind of city within a city, walled off from the rest of Night with designated points of entry manned by Kurt Hansen's Militech-commandos-turned-militia-soldiers. On the streets one can still see the remnants of Pacifica's never-completed redevelopment - luxury hotels, swimming pools, dazzlingly sumptuous mansions: once destined for glory, now a dilapadated mess. Machinery abandoned by construction workers is also present and many of the buildings are nothing more than crumbling, vacant husks.

The NCPD is forbidden to enter Dogtown proper, while Trauma Team rarely ventures inside due to the increased risk and the fact that hardly anyone in Dogtown has TT insurance. True enough, Hansen's people serve as local law enforcement, but are far from what one would call "police officers". Maybe they'll help, maybe they won't - their primary concern is ensuring the neighborhood doesn't descend into total anarchy. Small local squabbles and conflicts? Not worth their precious time.

So who lives in Dogtown? Mostly those on the run from corps, gangs or the NCPD. But ordinary people find themselves in the mix too - those pushed beyond the margins of society in Night City and who were brave or desperate enough to try their luck here.
